conversations.content: How much did GEICO spend on ads last year, and how has this amount changed over time?

Last year, GEICO spent $631 million on ads. To put that into perspective, this is up from $238 million in 2003 and a significant jump from $31 million in 1995, when Berkshire took control. It's been a remarkable increase, and we're committed to continuing this investment in advertising.
What's your perspective on the challenges of managing large organizations, and how does this relate to Berkshire's own growth?

Well, I've always been a bit skeptical about the ability of big entities to function well. Charlie Munger, my partner, and I have seen how size can make organizations slow-thinking, resistant to change, and even a bit smug. As Berkshire has grown to have 217,000 employees and nearly $100 billion in annual revenues, we've tried to stay mindful of these pitfalls. It's a challenge, but we're committed to staying agile and focused, even as we've become one of the larger players in the business world.
What was the outcome of your meeting with Eitan, Jacob, and Danny Goldman in Omaha, and how did it influence your decision to purchase ISCAR?

After spending a few hours with Eitan, Jacob, and Danny, I was convinced that they were extraordinarily talented managers who could be trusted to run the business. This meeting played a significant role in my decision to purchase 80% of ISCAR for $4 billion, as it gave me confidence in their ability to lead the company effectively.
What is the nature of ISCAR's business, and how do their products contribute to their customers' success?

ISCAR's business is quite straightforward - they produce small, consumable cutting tools used with large machine tools. The magic happens because of the talented people running the company, who continually develop tools that make their customers' machines more productive. Essentially, ISCAR makes money by helping its customers make more money, which is a recipe for continued success.
What kind of businesses has Fruit of Berkshire acquired recently and what impact do these acquisitions have on the company's sales and employee count?

Fruit has recently acquired Russell Corp., a leading producer of athletic apparel and uniforms, and the intimate apparel business of VF Corp. These acquisitions add about $2.2 billion to our sales and bring in around 23,000 new employees. It's a significant expansion, and I'm excited to have these new teams on board.
What kind of acquisitions is Berkshire focusing on, and why?

Charlie and I are focusing on the big ones - what we call 'elephants'. We need large acquisitions to make a dent in Berkshire's substantial cash flow. It's like the story of the two men searching for their wives in the grocery store; we're not looking for just anyone, we're looking for the 'gorgeous blonde' - the big, game-changing deals that will drive significant growth for our company.
What are your expectations for the insurance industry in 2007, specifically regarding the results from the bread-and-butter lines of insurance?

I expect our results from the bread-and-butter lines of insurance to deteriorate in 2007, though I think they will remain satisfactory. It's the super-cat insurance that's the big unknown, and that's where I see potential for significant impact.
How much are you willing to lose in a single event if you've been paid appropriately for assuming that risk?

We remain prepared to lose $6 billion in a single event, as long as we've been paid appropriately for assuming that risk. That's the key - we're not afraid of risk, but we do want to be compensated fairly for taking it on.
How do you approach risk in your business, particularly in terms of potential losses?

I approach risk by being prepared to lose a significant amount if the price is right. For instance, we're willing to lose $6 billion in a single event if we've been adequately compensated for taking on that risk. It's all about appropriate pricing - if the price reflects our evaluation of loss probabilities, we're in. But if it doesn't, we're out, no matter how small the exposure might be.
What led to your decision to sharply reduce wind exposures in the super-cat field?

We reduced our wind exposures because rates have fallen due to a flood of capital entering the super-cat field. It's a simple principle: be fearful when others are greedy, and be greedy when others are fearful. Right now, others are being greedy, so we're being cautious. It's the same behavior we use in financial markets - we don't want to take on risk at prices that don't make sense for us.
What was the primary source of information for the American public for most of the 20th Century?
That was newspapers, hands down. They were the go-to source for everything from sports and finance to politics.
In your 1991 letter to shareholders, what did you predict about the future of media businesses?
I said they would prove considerably less marvelous than many of us thought at the time. I knew the insulated world of newspapers was changing, and I wasn't optimistic about their future prospects.
What is the difference between 'real trade' and 'pseudo-trade' according to your perspective?

To me, real trade is when we exchange goods or services for other goods or services - it's a fair swap. On the other hand, pseudo-trade is when we import goods or services without exporting anything in return. It's like buying something on credit without having the money to pay for it.
What consequence of the U.S. spending binge did you predict last year that has now come true?

I predicted that the 'investment income' account of our country would turn negative, meaning foreigners would earn more on their U.S. investments than we do on our investments abroad. Unfortunately, that's exactly what happened in 2006. It's a sign that we've been living beyond our means and now we're paying the price.
What criteria do you and Charlie Munger look for when selecting a new director for the board?
We look for someone who is owner-oriented, business-savvy, interested, and truly independent. It's essential that our directors think like intelligent owners and can faithfully represent them.
Why do you think director compensation has increased significantly in recent years?

I believe it's because consultants, like the ones from Ratchet, Ratchet and Bingo, have been pushing for higher compensation packages. It's created a situation where some directors rely too heavily on these fees, which can compromise their independence.
How many employees does Berkshire have at its World Headquarters, and what is the total size of the space they occupy?

We have 19 employees at World Headquarters, and they occupy a total of 9,708 square feet of space. And if you include Charlie's space at World Headquarters West in Los Angeles, that adds another 655 square feet.
Can you give an example from your experience of how executives' financial behavior changes when they're spending their own money versus someone else's?

Well, let me tell you about Jimmy, the barber at Salomon. When the top brass had free haircuts, one executive would get a haircut every week. But when they had to start paying for it themselves, that executive suddenly decided he only needed a haircut every three weeks. It's a funny thing how the wallet can change one's perspective on what's necessary.
How do you and Charlie plan to price Berkshire's shares in relation to its intrinsic value?

Charlie and I aim to keep Berkshire's share price as close as possible to its intrinsic value, avoiding large discounts or premiums. We believe this approach will ultimately benefit our shareholders over time.
What's an example of how unrealistic expectations about investment returns can lead to poor decision-making, according to your allegory about the Gotrocks family?

Well, take private and public pension plans, for instance. They sometimes use overly optimistic investment assumptions to temporarily boost their earnings or delay tax increases. It's a bit like counting chickens before they hatch – and it can take decades for the truth to come out, by which time those responsible are long gone.
How does the 2-and-20 crowd's fee system work, and what's an example of how it affects investors?

Well, let me tell you - the 2-and-20 system is quite straightforward, but not exactly investor-friendly. Essentially, the manager takes 2% of your principal every year, no matter how they perform. And if they do happen to make a profit, they take 20% of that too. For instance, if a manager achieves a 10% gross return, they'd take 2% off the top and then 20% of the remaining 8%, leaving the investor with just 6.4%. It's a pretty lopsided deal, if you ask me.
Can you explain why you call the promise of above-average investment performance the 'adult version of Lake Woebegon'?

Ha! Yes, I call it that because, just like in Lake Woebegon where all the children are above average, the Wall Street crowd promises that everyone can achieve above-average performance. It's a statistical impossibility, of course, but they keep selling this dream to investors, and it's just not realistic. It's a fancy way of saying that someone's got to be below average, but nobody wants to hear that.
What is the main issue with the 2-and-20 arrangement, in your opinion?

The main issue is that it's a mathematically losing proposition for the investor, like the Gotrocks family. It's a deal where the people with experience, the 'hyper-helpers,' end up with the money, and the people with money end up with the experience - and not the good kind, if you know what I mean.
Can you describe Walter Schloss's investment approach, as you've observed it?

Walter's approach is straightforward and based on simple statistical methods he learned from Ben Graham. He doesn't rely on inside information or even much outside information. He and his son Edwin have kept things remarkably simple over the years, with minimal staff and overhead. It's a testament to the fact that you don't need a lot of bells and whistles to be a successful investor.
What was Walter's basic approach to selecting securities, and how did it differ from more complex investment strategies?

Walter's approach was pretty straightforward - he used simple statistical methods learned from Ben Graham to select securities. He didn't rely on fancy stuff like Modern Portfolio Theory, technical analysis, or complex algorithms. As Edwin put it, 'We try to buy stocks cheap.' That's it. And you know what? It worked beautifully for him over 47 years.
Did Walter's success come from just a few big winners, and could his results have been due to chance?

No, Walter's success wasn't just about hitting a few home runs. He invested in about 1,000 securities, mostly of a lackluster type, and still managed to dramatically surpass the S&P 500. And as for chance, I just don't buy it. If millions of investment managers had mimicked his trades, the luckiest of them wouldn't have come close to his record. There's no way his results over 47 years were due to luck.
What was the typical reaction of business schools teaching efficient market theory when they were presented with evidence that contradicted it, such as Walter's performance?

Well, I'd say they reacted in a pretty human way - they closed their eyes to the new evidence. Instead of studying Walter's performance and what it meant for their theory, they just kept on teaching efficient market theory as if it were gospel truth.
How did the widespread teaching of efficient market theory affect the investing landscape, according to your perspective?

It made my friend Walter's job a lot easier, that's for sure. If everyone else is taught that the price of every stock is always 'right' and that trying to evaluate businesses is useless, that's like telling all the other ships in the shipping business that the earth is flat. It gives you a nice advantage, let me tell you.
